channel.title: The Beautiful Universe: Chandra in HD
channel.description: High definition views of Chandra's exciting science

image.title: The Beautiful Universe: Chandra in HD

item.title: A Tour of Galaxy Gathering Brings Warmth
item.description: Two groups of galaxies located about 380 million light years from Earth are slamming into each other at about 4 million miles per hour.

item.title: A Tour of a Positive Feedback Black Hole
item.description: Astronomers have uncovered a black hole that may have sparked the birth of stars over a phenomenal distance of more than a million light years and across multiple galaxies.

item.title: A Tour of the Phoenix Cluster
item.description: Scientists have found stars forming at a furious rate in the Phoenix galaxy cluster. The supermassive black hole in the center of galaxy clusters usually stifles star formation, but the one in Phoenix is not.

item.title: A Tour of a Collision Between Four Galaxy Clusters in Abell 1758
item.description: When two pairs of galaxy clusters collide, the result is not four separate objects, but one giant galaxy cluster.

item.title: A Tour of Tycho's Supernova Remnant
item.description: A new image of the Tycho supernova remnant from Chandra reveals an intriguing pattern of bright clumps and fainter holes giving clues about its origin.

item.title: A Tour of Triplet Black Holes
item.description: A study using data from Chandra and other telescopes provides the strongest evidence yet for three supermassive black holes on a collision course.

item.title: A Tour of GSN 069
item.description: Astronomers found X-ray bursts repeating about every nine hours coming from the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy GSN 069.

item.title: A Tour of the Latest Look at "First Light" from Chandra
item.description: Over its two decades in space, Chandra X-ray Observatory has captured many spectacular images of cosmic phenomena. But perhaps its most iconic is the supernova remnant called Cassiopeia A.

item.title: A Tour of PSO167-13
item.description: Found at a time only about 850 million years after the Big Bang, this black hole could help us better understand an important epoch in the history of the Universe.

item.title: First Light: Celebrating 20 Years of Chandra Observatory
item.description: A scientific and engineering marvel, NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory has spent two decades (so far) exploring the cosmos unlike any other telescope. What it has found will astound you.

item.title: A Tour of Chandra Celebrates Its 20th Anniversary
item.description: To commemorate the 20th anniversary of NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, an assembly of new images has been released.

item.title: A Tour of Lensed Quasars
item.description: Astronomers have deployed a new technique to measure the spin of five supermassive black holes.

item.title: A Tour of the Coma Cluster
item.description: Does the Gas in Galaxy Clusters Flow Like Honey? Researchers used a deep Chandra dataset to study how the hot gas in the cluster behaves.

item.title: A Tour of Mrk 1216
item.description: A galaxy that has been isolated for billions of years has been found to have more dark matter in its core than expected.

item.title: A Tour of the Fornax Cluster
item.description: Scientists have found evidence that pairs of stars have been kicked out of their host galaxies.

item.title: A Tour of a New Signal for a Neutron Star Collision Discovered
item.description: A bright blast of X-rays from a source in a distant galaxy has led astronomers to a fascinating discovery.

item.title: A Tour of the Galactic Center Visualization
item.description: A new visualization provides viewers with an immersive, 360-degree, ultra-high-definition view of the center of our Galaxy.

item.title: A Tour of the Teacup
item.description: Fancy a cup of cosmic tea? This one isn't as calming as the ones on Earth. In a galaxy hosting a structure nicknamed the "Teacup," a galactic storm is raging.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 3079 Superbubbles
item.description: The galaxy NGC 3079, located about 67 million light years from Earth, contains two /"superbubbles/" unlike anything here on our planet.

item.title: A Tour of Where is the Universe Hiding its Missing Mass?
item.description: Astronomers have used Chandra to possibly identify the location of a third of the normal matter in the Universe created in the first billion years or so after the Big Bang.

item.title: A Tour of the Dark Energy Quasar Survey
item.description: Dark energy, a proposed force or energy that permeates all space and accelerates the Universe's expansion, may vary over time.

item.title: A Tour of Cygnus A
item.description: A ricocheting jet blasting from a giant black hole has been captured by NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: A Tour of ASASSN14-li
item.description: A tidal disruption event in a galaxy about 290 million light years from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of Archival Images
item.description: A collection of images including Chandra data that range in object type and distance.

item.title: A Tour of Abell 1033
item.description: Hidden in a distant galaxy cluster collision are wisps of gas resembling the starship Enterprise, an iconic spaceship from the "Star Trek" franchise.

item.title: A Tour of Kes 75
item.description: Scientists have confirmed the identity of the youngest known pulsar in the Milky Way galaxy. This result could provide astronomers new information about how some stars end their lives.

item.title: A Tour of GRB 150101B
item.description: A distant cosmic relative to the first source that astronomers detected in both gravitational waves and light may have been discovered.

item.title: A Tour of Abell 2142
item.description: Astronomers have used data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory to make heads and tails of a fascinating galactic system.

item.title: A Tour of Ring Galaxy AM 0644-741
item.description: Astronomers have used NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory to discover a ring of black holes or neutron stars in a galaxy 300 million light years from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of COSMOS Legacy Survey
item.description: These Chandra data have provided strong evidence for the existence of so-called intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs).

item.title: A Tour of RW Aur A
item.description: Chandra data indicates that a young star has likely destroyed and consumed an infant planet.

item.title: A Tour of Mrk 1216
item.description: Astronomers using Chandra found that black holes may have squelched star formation in small, yet massive galaxies known as "red nuggets".

item.title: A Tour of Alpha Centauri
item.description: A new study of Alpha Centauri indicates that any planets orbiting the two brightest stars are likely not being pummeled by large amounts of X-ray radiation from their host stars.

item.title: A Tour of GW170817
item.description: A new study using Chandra data of GW170817 indicates that the event that produced gravitational waves likely created the lowest mass black hole known.

item.title: A Tour of E0102
item.description: Astronomers have discovered a special kind of neutron star for the first time outside of the Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: A Tour of the Sagittarius A* Black Hole Swarm
item.description: Astronomers have discovered evidence for thousands of black holes located near the center of our Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 6231
item.description: By studying young clusters, astronomers hope to learn more about how stars-- including our Sun--are born

item.title: A Tour of the Cold Front in the Perseus Cluster
item.description: A gigantic and resilient "cold front" hurtling through the Perseus galaxy cluster has been studied using data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: A Tour of the Crab Nebula
item.description: A new composite image of the Crab Nebula features X-rays from Chandra, optical data from Hubble, and infrared data from Spitzer.

item.title: A Tour of Black Hole Growth in Chandra Deep Field South
item.description: Two groups of scientists, using data from Chandra X-ray Observatory and other telescopes, have found evidence that the growth of the biggest black holes in the Universe is outrunning the rate of formation of stars in the galaxies they inhabit.

item.title: A Tour of SDSS J1354+1327
item.description: The dining galaxy is known by its abbreviated name, J1354, and is about 800 million light years from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of the Galactic Center
item.description: A new visualization provides an exceptional virtual trip - complete with a 360-degree view - to the center of our home galaxy, the Milky Way.

item.title: A Tour of the Perseus Cluster
item.description: An innovative interpretation of X-ray data from a galaxy cluster could help scientists understand the nature of dark matter.

item.title: A Tour of Cassiopeia A Elements
item.description: Where do most of the elements essential for life on Earth come from? The answer: inside the furnaces of stars and the explosions that mark the end of some stars lives.

item.title: A Tour of J0045+41 in M31
item.description: An intriguing source has been discovered in the nearby Andromeda galaxy using data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and ground-based optical telescopes.

item.title: A Tour of Jupiter's Auroras
item.description: A new study using Chandra and XMM-Newton data reveals that the auroras at Jupiter's poles behave independently.

item.title: A Tour of GW170817
item.description: Astronomers have used NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory to make the first X-ray detection of a gravitational wave source.

item.title: A Tour of Dual Black Holes
item.description: Astronomers have found evidence for five dual supermassive black holes in the centers of galaxies, each containing millions of times the mass of the Sun.

item.title: A Tour of V745 SCO
item.description: For decades, astronomers have known about irregular outbursts from the double star system V745 Sco, which is located about 25,000 light years from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of GJ 176
item.description: X-rays emitted by a planet's host star may provide critical clues to just how hospitable a star system could be.

item.title: A Tour of IC 10
item.description: IC 10 is a starburst galaxy that has many new stars forming within it.

item.title: A Tour of W51
item.description: Because of its relative proximity, the giant molecular cloud W51 provides astronomers with an excellent opportunity to study how stars are forming in our Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: A Tour of Arp 299
item.description: What would happen if you took two galaxies and mixed them together over millions of years?

item.title: A Tour of R Aquarii
item.description: In biology, "symbiosis" refers to two organisms that live close to and interact with one another. Astronomers have long studied a class of stars-- called symbiotic stars--that co-exist in a similar way.

item.title: A Tour of Faint Active Nuclei in Chandra Deep Field South
item.description: Astronomers have determined the Big Bang occurred about 13.8 billion years ago and have evidence from the SDSS that supermassive black holes with masses of about a billion times that of the sun existed by about 12.8 billion years ago.

item.title: A Tour of CXO J101527.2+625911
item.description: Giant black holes are generally stationary objects, sitting at the centers of most galaxies. However, using data from NASAs Chandra X-ray Observatory and other telescopes, astronomers recently hunted down a supermassive black hole that may be on the move.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 4696
item.description: The Centaurus Cluster is a collection of hundreds of galaxies located about 145 million light years from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of CDF-S Transient XT1
item.description: Scientists have discovered a mysterious flash of X-rays using Chandra X-ray Observatory, in the deepest X-ray image ever obtained.

item.title: A Tour of X9 in 47 Tucanae
item.description: In astronomy, a binary system is one where two objects are close enough that they orbit each other because they are gravitationally bound to one another.

item.title: A Tour of Supernova 1987A
item.description: Thirty years ago on February 24, 1987, observers in the southern hemisphere noticed a new object in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

item.title: A Tour of XJ1500+0154
item.description: Every so often, an object will pass too close to a black hole and be ripped apart by its intense gravitational forces.

item.title: Tour of Chandra Deep Field South
item.description: What happens when astronomers use Chandra to take a long look at the same patch of sky?

item.title: A Tour of Abell 3411
item.description: There are many extraordinary things in the Universe. For example, astronomers have found many examples of supermassive black holes erupting in powerful outbursts that can stretch for millions of miles.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 6357
item.description: Although there are no seasons in space, this cosmic vista invokes thoughts of a frosty winter landscape.

item.title: A Tour of SPT 0346-52
item.description: Astronomers have used Chandra X-ray Observatory and other telescopes to show that a very distant galaxy is undergoing an extraordinary boom of stellar construction.

item.title: A Tour of Cyg X-3's Little Friend
item.description: The story of how stars are born and eventually die can be a complicated one.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 5128 Flare
item.description: Astronomers have found a pair of extraordinary objects that dramatically burst in X-rays. This discovery, made using data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and ESA's XMM-Newton observatory, may represent a new class of explosive events.

item.title: A Tour of Chandra's Data Archives
item.description: Each year, Chandra X-ray Observatory helps celebrate American Archive Month by releasing a collection of images using X-ray data that have been stored in its archive.

item.title: Is the Sun Really a Giant Pokemon?
item.description: The Sun can create powerful storms capable of knocking out communication satellites and damaging electrical power systems on Earth.

item.title: A Tour of XJ1417+52
item.description: First discovered in observations from Chandra and XMM-Newton over a decade ago, this object has some interesting properties.

item.title: Tour of Pluto
item.description: During the summer of 2015, scientists and the public alike were treated to a flood of images and discoveries about Pluto as the New Horizon spacecraft made an unprecedented flyby of the dwarf planet.

item.title: Tour of RCW 103
item.description: When stars have more than about 8 times as much mass as the Sun, they end their lives in a spectacular explosion called a supernova.

item.title: A Tour of CL J1001
item.description: Galaxy clusters are incredibly important objects in the Universe since they are the largest objects in the Universe held together by gravity.

item.title: The AstrOlympics Project: PRESSURE
item.description: In science, pressure is defined as the amount of force over a given area. This means you can have the same amount of force over two different areas and end up with different results.

item.title: The AstrOlympics Project: MASS
item.description: The range of mass in our everyday lives and what we can appreciate in sporting events like the Olympics is just the tip of the proverbial iceberg - especially once we allow our minds to consider the wonders of space

item.title: The AstrOlympics: Time
item.description: Time and our ability to measure it accurately is also key for many frontiers of science, including astrophysics.

item.title: A Tour of G11.2-0.3
item.description: While they may sound like very different and distinct fields, astronomy and history can intersect in very interesting and important ways.

item.title: A Tour of IC 2497
item.description: A galaxy and a cloud of cool gas located about 680 million light years from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of GJ 3253
item.description: A low-mass red dwarf star about 31 light years away from Earth.

item.title: A Tour of GRB 140903A
item.description: Gamma-ray bursts are some of the most powerful explosions in the Universe.

item.title: The AstrOlympics Project: DISTANCE
item.description: Despite how large some Olympic distances may seem, they are just a tiny fraction of the lengths we see across space.

item.title: A Tour of VLA J2130+12
item.description: Astronomers have found many black holes both here in our Milky Way galaxy and beyond.

item.title: The AstrOlympics Project: SPEED
item.description: By converting speeds from common experiences into meters per second, we can use this as a reference point for exploring the enormous range of speeds around the world and across the Universe.

item.title: The AstrOlympics Project: ROTATION
item.description: In the Olympic Games, athletes often need to rotate in order to compete in their sports. We also find things in space that rotate.

item.title: A Tour of TW Hya
item.description: One of the most exciting developments in astronomy in the last couple of decades has been the discovery and study of planets around stars other than our Sun.

item.title: What Do Olympic Athletes and Objects in Space have in Common?
item.description: The AstrOlympics project explores the spectacular range of science that we can find both in the impressive feats of the Olympic Games as well as in cosmic phenomena throughout the Universe.

item.title: A Tour of Black Hole Seeds
item.description: The new results suggest that at least some of the supermassive black holes in the early Universe formed through this direct collapse method.

item.title: A Tour of Tycho's Supernova Remnant
item.description: In modern times, astronomers have observed the debris field from this explosion - what is now known as Tycho's supernova remnant - with many telescopes including the Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: A Tour of Galaxy Clusters
item.description: A new study tries to tackle the questions surrounding dark energy by examining properties of X-ray emission from galaxy clusters.

item.title: A Tour of Comets ISON and PanSTARRS
item.description: Recently, astronomers have performed such a study using observations with Chandra of two comets, named ISON and PanSTARRS.

item.title: A Tour of G1.9+0.3
item.description: A little more than a century ago, as seen from the Earth, a star exploded near the center of the Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: A Tour of Jupiter
item.description: A new study using data from Chandra X-ray Observatory has shown that storms from the Sun are triggering auroras in X-ray light.

item.title: A Tour of Frontier Fields
item.description: Two of these Frontier Fields galaxy clusters, going by their abbreviated names, are MACS J0416 and MACS J0717.

item.title: A Tour of B3 0727+409
item.description: Astronomers have used Chandra X-ray Observatory to discover a jet from a very distant supermassive black hole being illuminated by the oldest light in the Universe.

item.title: A Tour of Pictor A
item.description: The Universe produces phenomena that often surpass what science fiction can conjure.

item.title: A Tour of IDCS J1426.5+3508
item.description: New X-ray data from Chandra confirmed that IDCS J1426 was indeed enormous, weighing in at a whopping 500 trillion times the mass of our Sun.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 5195
item.description: Astronomers using Chandra X-ray Observatory have discovered evidence for powerful blasts produced by a giant black hole.

item.title: Bubbles, Bubbles, Everywhere
item.description: Bubbles represent important physical phenomena that can be found across many scales and in many different types of objects.

item.title: A Tour of Zwicky 8338
item.description: An extraordinary ribbon of hot gas trailing behind a galaxy like a tail has been discovered using data from Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: A Tour of IC 443
item.description: The Jellyfish Nebula, lying about 5,000 light years from Earth, is the remnant of a supernova that occurred over 10,000 years ago.

item.title: A Tour of SDSS J103842.59+484917.7
item.description: One hundred years ago this month, Albert Einstein published his theory of general relativity, one of the most important scientific achievements in the last century.

item.title: A Tour of Delta Orionis
item.description: Modern astronomers know that Delta Orionis is not simply one single star, but rather it is a complex multiple star system.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Teeny Tiny Planet Destroyer
item.description: Astronomers have recently discovered evidence that a planet may have been destroyed in our very own Galaxy.

item.title: A Tour of ASASSN-14li
item.description: When something, like a star or a planet, wanders too close to a black hole, it is usually not good news for that object.

item.title: Light Beyond the Bulb: Bent Light in Space
item.description: One of the most interesting characteristics of light is that the path that it travels can bend.

item.title: Banking X-ray Data for the Future
item.description: Chandra X-ray Observatory has collected data for over sixteen years on thousands of different objects throughout the Universe.

item.title: Tour of Phoenix Cluster
item.description: This galaxy cluster, which was found about 5.7 billion light years from Earth, shattered several important astronomical records.

item.title: Tour of Sgr A*
item.description: At the heart of the Milky Way galaxy, there is a supermassive black hole that has the mass equivalent of some four million Suns.

item.title: Chandra Sketches: Highlights of Light
item.description: Light comes in different forms. The light that we see with our eyes is just a fraction of all light.

item.title: Chandra Sketches: Our Connection With Light
item.description: We rely on light - both natural and artificial - to brighten and power our world, but also for so much more.

item.title: Tour of Abell 1033
item.description: Understanding how clusters grow is critical to tracking how the Universe itself evolves over time.

item.title: A Tour of RGG 118
item.description: Oxymorons are often thought of as gaffes in language, but a new black hole discovery shows they can also represent important scientific advances.

item.title: Coloring the Universe - Part 2
item.description: Last time, we looked at the electromagnetic spectrum. This time we'll look at how astronomical images are made.

item.title: Coloring the Universe - Part 1
item.description: An astronomer's toolkit consists of many kinds of light, across the electromagnetic spectrum.

item.title: Chandra's Sweet Sixteen
item.description: This year, NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory celebrates its own "sweet 16."

item.title: A Tour of PSR B1259-63/LS 2883
item.description: A fast-moving pulsar appears to have punched a hole in a disk of gas around its companion star and launched a fragment of the disk outward at a speed of about 4 million miles per hour.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 1333
item.description: While fireworks only last a short time here on Earth, a bundle of cosmic sparklers in a nearby cluster of stars will be going off for a very long time.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 5813
item.description: Galaxy groups are families of galaxies that are bound together by gravity. They are very similar to their larger cousins, galaxy clusters.

item.title: Light Beyond the Bulb: Over and Beyond the Rainbow
item.description: While scientists and philosophers have tried to figure out exactly what light is for millennia, it's only been in the past several hundred years or so that we've really started to figure it out.

item.title: A Tour of Circinus X-1
item.description: These rings are light echoes, similar to sound echoes that we may experience here on Earth.

item.title: Light Beyond the Bulb: Intro to Light
item.description: The year 2015 has been declared to be the International Year of Light and Light-based Technologies by the United Nations.

item.title: A Tour of Space-time Foam
item.description: Since space-time foam, as it is called, is so tiny, scientists cannot observe it directly.

item.title: Chandra Sketches: Chandra Explained
item.description: Chandra does not look at light that we can see with our eyes. It detects x-rays from the Universe.

item.title: A Tour of SGR 1745-2900
item.description: A new study reveals that the X-ray output from SGR 1745-2900 is dropping more slowly than for other magnetars, and its surface is hotter than expected.

item.title: A Tour of 3 Quasars
item.description: A group of unusual giant black holes may be consuming excessive amounts of matter, according to a new study using NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: Chandra Sketches: Clara's Launch
item.description: My mom works for NASA, for a telescope that studies X-rays from space. She told me about how the telescope, called Chandra, was launched into space aboard the Space Shuttle.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 6388
item.description: Chandra's excellent X-ray vision enabled the astronomers to determine that the X-rays from NGC 6388 were not coming from a black hole at the center of the cluster.

item.title: Space Scoop: Not Your Average Superhero
item.description: A black hole is formed when a massive star is squashed into an incredibly tiny volume.

item.title: A Tour of GK Persei
item.description: In space, explosions of actual stars are a focus for scientists who hope to better understand the lifecycle of their births, lives, and deaths.

item.title: Space Scoop: Weather Forecast Predicts Rain Around Black Holes
item.description: On Earth, precipitation happens when water is heated by the Sun and forms steam. Sometimes, something similar happens in galaxies.

item.title: A Tour of Abell 2597
item.description: Researchers used Chandra to look at some of the largest known galaxies lying in the middle of galaxy clusters.

item.title: A Tour of NGC 2276
item.description: Astronomers found that this intermediate-mass black hole is producing a jet that appears to be squelching the formation of stars around it.

item.title: Space Scoop: Megaflares Shed Light On Our Black Hole
item.description: Supermassive black holes are famous for their ability to swallow anything - even light.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Most Attractive Stars in the Universe
item.description: Astronomers think magnetars may be created when some massive stars die in a supernova explosion.

item.title: A Tour of G299.2-2.9
item.description: This new Chandra image of G299 shows a beautiful and intricate structure in the expanding remains of the shattered star.

item.title: A Tour of IYL 2015
item.description: To recognize the start of IYL, the Chandra X-ray Center is releasing a collection of images that combine data from telescopes tuned to different wavelengths of light.

item.title: Introduction to OpenFITS
item.description: We would like to step through our new tutorial on creating a multiwavelength composite image of M101 using GIMP.

item.title: Tour of Sagittarius A*
item.description: Over the years, astronomers have learned many things about Sagittarius A* and it continues to surprise and intrigue scientists to this day.

item.title: A Tour of il Gioiello Cluster
item.description: This galaxy cluster is officially known as XDCP J0044.0-2033. Perhaps not surprisingly, astronomers decided to give a nickname to this mouthful of a cluster name.

item.title: Hour of Code
item.description: Working with NASA and other data from exploded stars, to star-forming regions, to the area around black holes, students learn basic coding (for beginners - no experience required) and follow a video tutorial to create a real world application of science, technology and even art.

item.title: Tour of NGC 2207
item.description: When galaxies get together, there is also the chance of a spectacular light show.

item.title: Space Scoop: Breaking Free From a Cosmic Cocoon
item.description: The shock wave from the supernova is absorbed by the star's outer shells of gas and dust, which escaped from the star before the explosion.

item.title: Chandra - 15 Years and Counting
item.description: Celebrating 15 years of science with NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory: Chandra allows scientists from around the world to obtain X-ray images of exotic environments to help understand the structure and evolution of the universe.

item.title: Tour of Sagittarius A
item.description: One of the biggest mysteries in astrophysics today is figuring out where mysterious particles called neutrinos come from.

item.title: Space Scoop: Please Don't Stop the Music!
item.description: Astronomers already know that the black hole at the centre of a collection of galaxies called the Perseus Cluster is powerful enough to make a very deep sound.

item.title: A Tour of Perseus and Virgo Clusters
item.description: Now researchers have direct evidence for just how that energy keeps the gas in the entire galaxy cluster so hot.

item.title: Chandra's Archives Come to Life
item.description: Every year, NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory looks at hundreds of objects throughout space to help expand our understanding of the Universe.

item.title: A Tour of M82X-2
item.description: Ultraluminous X-ray Sources, or ULXs, are unusual objects. They are rare and, as their name implies, give off enormous amounts of X-rays.

item.title: Space Scoop: At the End of the Rainbow
item.description: If we look deeper, space has a lot more to offer than what our eyes can see.

item.title: Tour of WASP-18
item.description: A new study using data from Chandra X-ray Observatory has shown that a planet is making the star that it orbits act much older than it actually is.

item.title: A Tour of Puppis A
item.description: The destructive results of a powerful supernova explosion are seen in a delicate tapestry of X-ray light in this new image.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Butterfly Hunter
item.description: Astronomers using Chandra X-ray Observatory have set out on a hunt, to look at as many planetary nebulae as they can.

item.title: A Tour of Eta Carinae
item.description: New Chandra data are helping astronomers better understand how the two stars in Eta Carinae interact with one another through powerful winds blowing off their surfaces.

item.title: Space Scoop: Supernova Blast Provides Clues to Age of Binary Star System
item.description: A new study of an X-ray binary called Circinus X-1 found that it is less than 4,600 years old.

item.title: Space Scoop: Archaeologists of the Universe
item.description: This picture shows the aftermath of a collision between two huge groups of galaxies, which are called galaxy clusters.

item.title: A Tour of M82 SN2014J
item.description: Earlier this year, astronomers discovered one of the closest supernovas in decades.

item.title: Chandra X-ray Observatory Celebrates 15th Anniversary
item.description: To celebrate the 15th anniversary of Chandra X-ray Observatory, we have released four new images of supernova remnants.

item.title: Space Scoop: X-ray Vision Reveals the Insides of Stars
item.description: Each of these four fabulous photographs shows the remains of an exploded star - called a supernova remnant.

item.title: A Tour of The Big, Bad & Beautiful Universe with Chandra
item.description: In fifteen years of operation, the Chandra X-ray Observatory has given us a view of the universe that is largely hidden from telescopes sensitive only to visible light.

item.title: A Tour of M106
item.description: NGC 4258, also known as Messier 106, is a spiral galaxy like the Milky Way. This galaxy is famous, however, for something that our Galaxy doesn't have - two extra spiral arms that glow in X-ray, optical, and radio light.

item.title: A Tour of Perseus
item.description: A team of astronomers has used Chandra X-ray Observatory and XMM-Newton to study a large group of galaxy clusters with a surprising result.

item.title: Space Scoop: X-rays Uncover Black Holes Dancing With Normal Stars
item.description: This photograph shows the flamboyant spiral galaxy called Messier 51.

item.title: A Tour of M51
item.description: Like the Milky Way, the Whirlpool is a spiral galaxy with spectacular arms of stars and dust.

item.title: Space Scoop: Collecting Clues to a Cosmic Crime
item.description: The galaxy is called ESO 137-001 and in reality it is hidden from our view by a thick fog of space dust.

item.title: Space Scoop: Galaxy Hits a Cosmic Bullseye
item.description: The Universe is vast and largely made up of empty space, but cosmic collisions still happen pretty often.

item.title: A Tour of Flame Nebula
item.description: A new study of NGC 2024 and the Orion Nebula Cluster show stars on the outskirts of these clusters are older than those in the middle.

item.title: A Tour of Astro Pro-Am
item.description: Four images of galaxies that have been made using data from both amateur and professional telescopes.

item.title: Space Scoop: Blowing Bubbles
item.description: This is a gas bubble inside a previously blown bubble, or nebula, like you can see in this image.

item.title: Space Scoop: A Field Trip to Star School
item.description: When astronomers want to study young stars, this cluster - called Cygnus OB2 - is one of the first places they look.

item.title: Space Scoop: Sweeping Supernovas
item.description: This space photograph shows a supernova remnant that is sweeping up a remarkable amount of material.

item.title: Pillars of Erosion
item.description: Erosion is what happens when some sort of force wears down an object.

item.title: A Tour of DEM L241
item.description: When a massive star runs out fuel, it collapses and explodes as a supernova.

item.title: Tour of RX J1131-1231
item.description: Astronomers have directly measured the spin of a supermassive black hole in a quasar that is located 6 billion light years away.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Galactic Empire
item.description: Our galaxy, the Milky Way, is more than just a giant barred spiral containing hundreds of billions of stars.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Space Olympics
item.description: Most stars are like long-distance marathon runners, as they are constantly moving in space throughout their lifetimes.

item.title: A Tour of IGR J11014-6103
item.description: This object is a pulsar, the spinning dense core that remains after a massive star has exploded and collapsed.

item.title: Space Scoop: Super-Sized Space Spider!
item.description: Astronomers had to combine observations made with two space telescopes to create this photo.

item.title: A New Look at an Old Friend
item.description: This galaxy, at a distance of about 12 million light years from Earth, contains a gargantuan jet blasting away from a central supermassive black hole.

item.title: Space Scoop: I Can See Your Halo
item.description: Light from the nearest star outside our solar system has to travel through empty black space for 4.2 years before it reaches our eyes.

item.title: Space Scoop: A Flare for the Dramatic
item.description: Magnetars are some of the most extreme objects known in the Universe. These stars were given their name because they are very strong magnets.

item.title: Tour of AM CVn
item.description: In the middle of the twentieth century, an unusual star was spotted in the constellation of Canes Venatici.

item.title: 2013: A Year with the Chandra X-ray Observatory
item.description: The Chandra images included in this brief 2013 retrospective are drawn from dozens of images.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Big Explosion No One Saw
item.description: About once or twice every 100 years, a gigantic nuclear bomb detonates in our Galaxy.

item.title: Space Scoop: Beautiful But Deadly
item.description: It seems that there is a twist in nature: the more beautiful something is, the more deadly it also might be.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Mysterious Afterlife of Stellar Giants
item.description: Neutron stars are the ultra-dense cores left behind after a massive star reaches the end of its life and explodes.

item.title: Sgr A jet in 60 Seconds
item.description: Jets of high-energy particles are found throughout the Universe on large and small scales.

item.title: Smithsonian X 3D Explorer
item.description: One of the most famous objects in the sky - the Cassiopeia A supernova remnant - is now on display like never before.

item.title: Space Scoop: A Study in Supernovas
item.description: Astronomers have to be good at solving puzzles by piecing together clues and evidence.

item.title: Space Scoop: A Colossal Cosmic Crash
item.description: In this picture, a galactic collision is taking place between the grand spiral galaxy and the tiny dwarf galaxy that you can see to its left.

item.title: Space Scoop: Growth of the Coma Colossus
item.description: This picture shows the very large, very distant and very gassy Coma Cluster.

item.title: Chandra Archive 2013 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The Chandra Data Archive plays a central role in the mission by enabling the astronomical community access to data collected by the observatory.

item.title: Space Scoop: Did Somebody Call the Ghostbusters?
item.description: This spooky new image shows a massive star in its afterlife. You could say it's a 'ghost star'.

item.title: Space Scoop: Circus in the Sky
item.description: This object was first spotted in 1757, but today we are still discovering new details about it.

item.title: Seeds of Life Across the Universe
item.description: There is also seeding taking place on a much bigger stage - a cosmic one.

item.title: M60-UCD1 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The galaxy, known as M60-UCD1, is located about 54 million light years from Earth.

item.title: Coma Cluster in 60 Seconds
item.description: Galaxy clusters are the largest structures in the Universe held together by gravity.

item.title: Space Scoop: Beyond the Horizon
item.description: It took some pretty impressive technology to get these pictures, which wasn't available to our ancient ancestors.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Invisible Universe Exposed
item.description: Pictures of space are often gorgeous. But one of the most exciting things about them is that, very often, they show us things that are invisible to the human eye.

item.title: Sagittarius A* in 60 Seconds
item.description: Scientists have long known that the giant black hole at the center of the Milky Way is a particularly poor eater.

item.title: Space Scoop: Goodness Gracious, Great Ball of Fire!
item.description: HD 189733 is an enormous gas giant, over 100 times bigger than Earth.

item.title: NGC 1232 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The hot gas cloud is likely caused by a collision between a dwarf galaxy and a much larger galaxy called NGC 1232.

item.title: HD 189733 in 60 Seconds
item.description: NASA's Chandra Sees Eclipsing Planet in X-rays for First Time

item.title: NGC 2392 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Stars like the Sun can become remarkably photogenic at the end of their life.

item.title: G1.9+0.3 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers estimate that a star explodes as a supernova in our Galaxy, on average, about twice per century.

item.title: M31 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Many consider Andromeda, also known as Messier 31, to be a sister galaxy to our own Milky Way.

item.title: The Flow of Electric Charge
item.description: While most of us use electricity every day without thinking about it, maybe take a moment to look around.

item.title: SGR 0418+5729 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A magnetar is a type of neutron star that occasionally generates bursts of X-rays.

item.title: 4C+29.30 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers think that just about every galaxy contains a giant, or supermassive, black hole at their center.

item.title: Heaven and Earth
item.description: There are patterns of beauty across our Earth and throughout the Universe.

item.title: STOP for Science: That's Fast
item.description: Most of us have heard the story of the tortoise and the hare. The tortoise is slow and the hare is fast. But what exactly does this mean?

item.title: NGC 6240 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Two large galaxies are colliding and scientists have used Chandra to make a detailed study of an enormous cloud of hot gas that surrounds them.

item.title: SN1006 In 60 Seconds
item.description: The new Chandra data provide new details about SN 1006.

item.title: Shadows: Light That Does Not Pass
item.description: Shadows occur on other planets as well. One excellent place to look for shadows in our Solar System is the planet Jupiter.

item.title: The Shape of Speed
item.description: Bow waves are not just found in duck ponds. Rather they can be anywhere in water, air, or even space where an object is moving quickly enough.

item.title: NGC 602 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The Small Magellanic Cloud - also known as the SMC - is one of the closest galaxies to the Milky Way.

item.title: STOP for Science: When Stars Go Boom
item.description: Our Sun is a star. In fact, it is the closest star we'll ever see. The Sun is about 5 billion years old and will live for about 5 billion more. But not all stars live this long.

item.title: Kepler Supernova Remnant in 60 Seconds
item.description: Over 400 years ago, Johannes Kepler and many others witnessed the appearance of a new "star" in the sky.

item.title: Space Scoop: The Star That Lived Two Lives
item.description: In 1604, a new star appeared in the night sky. It shone brighter than all the other stars, and for three weeks, it was even visible during the day!

item.title: 47 Tucanae in 60 Seconds
item.description: Neutron stars are the ultra-dense cores that are often left behind after massive stars run out of fuel and collapse.

item.title: Learn About Stars
item.description: Stars appear to be permanent fixtures of the night sky. However, stars are like people. They are born, live a lifetime, and ultimately die.

item.title: W49B in 60 Seconds
item.description: The supernova remnant known as W49B is, let's say, a bit unorthodox looking. Many supernova remnants appear rather spherical in shape.

item.title: Learn About Solar System
item.description: One star, eight planets, and a myriad of moons, comets and asteroids. This is the Earth's local neighborhood, known as the Solar System.

item.title: Ice Core Records: From Volcanoes to Supernovas (Part II)
item.description: While astronomers know that Cassiopeia A, or Cas A for short, is the aftermath of a massive star that exploded, it is unclear exactly when the explosion took place.

item.title: DEM L50 in 60 Seconds
item.description: DEM L50 is what astronomers call a superbubble. These objects are found in regions where massive stars have formed, raced through their evolution, and exploded as supernovas.

item.title: Chandra Images in 2012
item.description: The Chandra images included in this short 2012 retrospective are drawn from dozens of images posted on our website (from among hundreds taken) in the past year to show the breadth and depth of research done using Chandra.

item.title: Vela Pulsar in 60 Seconds
item.description: Unlike with some Hollywood films, a sequel of a movie from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory is better than the first.

item.title: Learn About Supernovas
item.description: Supernovas are some of the most dramatic events in the cosmos. These titanic events send shockwaves rumbling through space and create giant bubbles of gas that have been superheated to millions of degrees.

item.title: Learn About Black Holes
item.description: If a star has three times or more the mass of the sun and collapses, it can form a black hole.

item.title: A Bend in the Road
item.description: There are many things around us that bend. Straws bend. Rivers bend. But did you know that light also bends?

item.title: PKS 0745 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Some of the biggest black holes in the Universe may actually be even bigger than previously thought.

item.title: NGC 3627 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The spiral galaxy NGC 3627 is located about 30 million light years from Earth. Astronomers recently completed a survey of galaxies to look for supermassive black holes.

item.title: NGC 922 in 60 Seconds
item.description: By comparing NGC 922 to galaxies with different mixtures of elements, astronomers hope to master the ideal recipe for what it takes to make these large black holes.

item.title: When Atoms Collide
item.description: Where can we observe light emitted by atoms? The answer: Here, there, and everywhere.

item.title: GB 1428+4217 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The most distant jet in X-ray light has been discovered using data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: Abell 30 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A planetary nebula is a phase of stellar evolution that the sun should experience several billion years from now, when it expands to become a red giant.

item.title: Cygnus OB2 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The Milky Way and other galaxies in the universe are home to many star clusters and associations that each contain hundreds to thousands of hot, massive, young stars.

item.title: Spirals in Nature
item.description: Looking at a hurricane from this point of view, we can see that the storm is, in fact, a giant spiral shape.

item.title: Learn About the Milky Way
item.description: The word galaxy comes from the Greek word meaning "milky circle" or the more familiar Milky Way.

item.title: NGC 4178 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A supermassive black hole with one of the lowest masses ever observed has been spotted in the middle of a galaxy, using NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and several other observatories.

item.title: Planetary Nebula Survey
item.description: A planetary nebula is a phase of stellar evolution that the sun should experience several billion years from now, when it expands to become a red giant.

item.title: WIND - Here, There and Everywhere
item.description: Wind is an excellent example of a phenomenon that happens here, there, and everywhere.

item.title: Kepler's Supernova Remnant in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image of Kepler's supernova remnant shows the expanding ball of debris from a supernova explosion in our galaxy.

item.title: NGC 1929 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The star cluster known as NGC 1929 is embedded in a cloud of gas and dust, which astronomers call the N44 nebula.

item.title: Phoenix Cluster in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers have found an extraordinary galaxy cluster -- one of the largest objects in the Universe -- that is breaking several important cosmic records.

item.title: SN 1957D in M83 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Over fifty years ago, a supernova was discovered in M83, a spiral galaxy about 15 million light years from Earth.

item.title: IGR J11014-6103 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A pulsar found racing away from a supernova remnant about 30,000 light years from Earth.

item.title: NGC 4342 and NGC 4291 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers think that just about every galaxy has a giant black hole at its center.

item.title: CID-42 in 60 Seconds
item.description: At the center of a galaxy some 4 billion light years from Earth, something extraordinary is happening. This galaxy, known as CID-42, contains a giant black hole.

item.title: SN 2010jl in 60 Seconds
item.description: Why are some supernovas much more powerful than others? Astronomers are still trying to figure that out, but one new discovery may help answer the question.

item.title: M83 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Since the 1980s, astronomers have known about a mysterious class of objects that they call "ultraluminous X-ray sources," or ULXs.

item.title: Musket Ball Cluster in 60 Seconds
item.description: Using a combination of powerful observatories in space and on the ground, astronomers have discovered a violent collision between two galaxy clusters.

item.title: Stop for Science: Listening to Light
item.description: When we look up on a dark night, we see a sky filled with stars. The light from a star, like the light from a flashlight or a lightning bug, is one form of electromagnetic radiation.

item.title: Cassiopeia A in 60 Seconds
item.description: Over three hundred years ago, a very large star ran out of fuel and collapsed. This event created an explosion, known as a supernova, which then produced an expanding field of debris.

item.title: A Tour of 3C 186: An Interview with Dr. Aneta Siemiginowska
item.description: A galaxy cluster containing a structure never previously seen so far from Earth has been observed by Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: Abell 383 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Dark matter is mysterious. We know that it is invisible material that does not emit or absorb any type of light, but we can detect it through the gravitational effects it has on material we can see.

item.title: Sgr A* in 60 Seconds
item.description: Over several years, astronomers have noticed flares in X-ray light from the black hole at the center of the Milky Way.

item.title: G350.1-0.3 in 60 Seconds
item.description: G350.1+0.3 is a young and exceptionally bright supernova remnant located nearly 15,000 light years from Earth toward the center of the Milky Way.

item.title: Ice Core Records: From Volcanoes to Supernovas
item.description: Researchers have been traveling for decades to some of the coldest places on the planet to uncover some of the secrets from space that have been left behind on Earth.

item.title: El Gordo (ACT J0102-4915) in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers using the Chandra X-ray Observatory and ground-based optical telescopes have discovered an extraordinary galaxy cluster some 7.2 billion light years from Earth.

item.title: SXP 1062 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The Milky Way galaxy has several small satellite galaxies very close to it. One of them is called the Small Magellanic Cloud.

item.title: Abell 2052 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The galaxy cluster Abell 2052 is found some 480 million light years from Earth. At the center of Abell 2052 is a giant elliptical galaxy, and within that is a supermassive black hole.

item.title: Tarantula Nebula in 60 Seconds
item.description: 30 Doradus is a place where stars are born literally. This region, which is also known as the Tarantula Nebula, is located about 160,000 light years from Earth.

item.title: Cygnus X-1 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Over three decades ago, Stephen Hawking placed, and eventually lost, a bet against the existence of a black hole in Cygnus X-1.

item.title: RCW 86 in 60 Seconds
item.description: In 185 A.D., Chinese astronomers noted a "guest star" that mysteriously appeared in the sky and stayed for about 8 months.

item.title: CID 1711 and CID 3083 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers have recently completed a large survey of the sky using some of the powerful telescopes both on the ground and in space.

item.title: G299.2-2.9 in 60 Seconds
item.description: G299.2-2.9 is an intriguing supernova remnant found about 16,000 light years away in the Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: NGC 281 in 60 Seconds
item.description: High-mass stars are important because they are responsible for much of the energy pumped into a galaxy over its lifetime.

item.title: CoRoT-2A in 60 Seconds
item.description: In recent years, astronomers have found hundreds of planets orbiting stars other than our Sun.

item.title: NGC 3393 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers using NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory have discovered the first pair of supermassive black holes in a spiral galaxy similar to the Milky Way.

item.title: VV 340 in 60 Seconds
item.description: VV 340, also known as Arp 302, is a textbook example of colliding galaxies seen in the very early stages of their interaction.

item.title: A Tour of the Crab
item.description: The Crab Nebula is one of the brightest sources of high-energy radiation in the sky.

item.title: NGC 3115 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This is NGC 3115, a galaxy located about 32 million light years from Earth. This composite image contains X-rays from Chandra as well as optical data from the Very Large Telescope.

item.title: PSR J0357+3205 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A spinning neutron star is tied to a mysterious tail, or is it? Astronomers using NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory have found a long, X-ray bright tail streaming away from the pulsar known as PSR J0357.

item.title: Abell 2744 in 60 Seconds
item.description: One of the most complicated and dramatic collisions ever seen between galaxy clusters is captured in this new composite image.

item.title: CDFS in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image is what is known as the Chandra Deep Field South, a 4-million-second exposure made by NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: Carina Nebula in 60 Seconds
item.description: Located in the Sagittarius-Carina arm of the Milky Way a mere 7,500 light years from Earth, the Carina Nebula is one of the best places to study how massive stars live and die.

item.title: Tycho's Supernova Remnant in 60 Seconds
item.description: New research using Chandra data of the Tycho supernova remnant provides astronomers with clues to what triggered the original supernova explosion.

item.title: Massive Stars in the Milky Way in 60 Seconds
item.description: Like looking for Easter eggs in a lawn of long grass, the hunt for the Milky Way's most massive stars takes persistence and sharp eyes and powerful telescopes that can see different types of light.

item.title: Tycho in 60 Seconds
item.description: Over four hundred years ago, the Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe studied the explosion of a star that later became known as Tycho's supernova.

item.title: Cassiopeia A in 60 Seconds
item.description: A new discovery from a famous exploded star has provided the first evidence for a bizarre state of matter in its core.

item.title: Arp 147 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image shows Arp 147, a pair of interacting galaxies some 430 million light years from Earth.

item.title: GRS 1915+105 in 60 Seconds
item.description: GRS 1915+105, or GRS 1915 for short, is a special system. Not only does it contain a black hole some 14 times more massive than the Sun in orbit with a companion star, it also has a heartbeat.

item.title: A Tour of SN 1979C
item.description: The youngest known black hole in our cosmic neighborhood may have been found using NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and other telescopes.

item.title: A Tour of GOODS
item.description: The most powerful telescopes on the ground and in space have joined forces over the last decade in a unique observing campaign, known as GOODS, which reaches across the spectrum and deep back into cosmic time.

item.title: G327.1-1.1 in 60 Seconds
item.description: G327.1-1.1 is the aftermath of a massive star that exploded as a supernova in the Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: Rosette Nebula in 60 Seconds
item.description: This spectacular image shows the Rosette star formation region, which is located about 5,000 light years from Earth.

item.title: Super-volcano M87 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This composite image from NASAs Chandra X-ray Observatory with radio data from the Very Large Array shows a cosmic volcano being driven by a black hole in the center of the M87 galaxy.

item.title: CH Cyg in 60 Seconds
item.description: Deep within this optical image lies an intriguing system known as CH Cyg. CH Cyg is a binary star system containing a white dwarf that feeds from the wind of a red giant star.

item.title: Antennae in 60 Seconds
item.description: This beautiful new image shows two colliding galaxies as seen by NASA's Great Observatories.

item.title: NGC 7793 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This composite image shows the nearby galaxy NGC 7793 that contains a powerful microquasar in its outskirts.

item.title: M31 Black Hole in 60 Seconds
item.description: For over a decade, astronomers have been using the Chandra X-ray Observatory to monitor the supermassive black hole in the center of Andromeda, the Milky Way's sister galaxy.

item.title: M82 in 60 Seconds
item.description: We begin with a composite image of the nearby starburst galaxy M82 that contains X-rays from Chandra in blue, optical data from Hubble in green and orange, and infrared data from Spitzer in red.

item.title: N49 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This beautiful image shows N49, which is the aftermath of a supernova explosion in the Large Magellanic Cloud.

item.title: Abell 3376 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This composite image of the galaxy cluster Abell 3376 shows X-ray data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory and the ROSAT telescope along with an optical image from the Digitized Sky Survey and radio emission observed by the Very Large Array.

item.title: G54.1+0.3 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Spitzer Space Telescope were combined to create this image of the dusty remains of a collapsed star.

item.title: SDSS J1254+0846 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Two quasars have been caught in the act of merging, thanks to this new image.

item.title: NGC 1068 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image shows one of the nearest and brightest galaxies to the Milky Way that contains a rapidly growing supermassive black hole known as NGC 1068.

item.title: ESO 137 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Two spectacular tails of X-ray emission have been seen trailing behind a galaxy known as ESO 137.

item.title: M31 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image of M31 represents a study of six elliptical galaxies that Chandra made to determine what causes an important type of supernova.

item.title: NGC 1399 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Evidence from Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Magellan telescopes in Chile suggest that a star has been torn apart by an intermediate-mass black hole.

item.title: Sagittarius A* in 60 Seconds
item.description: Astronomers have long known that the supermassive black hole at the center of our Milky Way galaxy is a particularly poor eater.

item.title: Best of The Beautiful Universe
item.description: In its first decade of exploration, Chandra has expanded our view of the universe with its unrivaled ability to create high-resolution X-ray images of cosmic phenomena.

item.title: Chandras Extraordinary Universe
item.description: In ten years of operation, the Chandra X-ray Observatory has transformed our view of the high-energy universe.

item.title: Multiwavelength Crab Nebula in 60 Seconds
item.description: The Crab Nebula is one of the most studied objects in the night sky. This version of the Crab Nebula combines data from three different telescopes.

item.title: Multiwavelength Galactic Center in 60 Seconds
item.description: This never-before-seen view of the turbulent heart of our Milky Way combines a near-infrared view from Hubble, an infrared image from Spitzer, and X-ray data from Chandra.

item.title: The Cassiopeia A in 60 Seconds
item.description: Cassiopeia A is a supernova remnant found embedded in the constellation that bears its name, which is known as the queen in Greek mythology.

item.title: JKCS041 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The most distant galaxy cluster yet has been found some 10.2 billion light-years from Earth.

item.title: NGC 6240 in 60 Seconds
item.description: NGC 6240 is a system in which two supermassive black holes are a mere 3,000 light years apart, virtually nothing in astronomical terms.

item.title: Galactic Center in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image from the Chandra X-ray Observatory reveals a wealth of exotic objects and high-energy features at the center of our Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: Hydra A in 60 Seconds
item.description: This composite image of the Hydra A galaxy cluster shows 10-million-degree gas observed by Chandra and jets of radio emission observed by the Very Large Array.

item.title: Cepheus B in 60 Seconds
item.description: A new study from two of NASA's "Great Observatories" provides fresh insight into how some stars are born, along with a beautiful new image of a stellar nursery in our own Milky Way Galaxy.

item.title: Introductory Trailer to Chandra
item.description: In Florence, Italy, in the year 1609, the world changed. Using a small telescope, Galileo proved that the Earth is not distinct from the universe, but part of it. And he showed that there is much more to the universe than we see with the naked eye.

item.title: E0102 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The supernova remnant known as E0102 was one of the targets that Chandra first observed after its launch in 1999.

item.title: Stephans Quintet in 60 Seconds
item.description: This beautiful image gives a new look at Stephans Quintet, a compact group of galaxies discovered about 130 years ago and located about 280 million light years from Earth.

item.title: GRS 1915 in 60 Seconds
item.description: We start with an optical and infrared image that shows the crowded area around the object known as GRS 1915+105, or GRS 1915 for short.

item.title: Galactic Ridge in 60 Seconds
item.description: This sequence begins with an infrared view from the Spitzer Space Telescope of the central region of the Milky Way.

item.title: MacsJ0717 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image contains one of the most complex galaxy clusters known, which is located about 5.4 billion light years from Earth.

item.title: Medusa in 60 Seconds
item.description: NGC 4194 is a galaxy that is found about 110 million light years from Earth.

item.title: 30 Doradus in 60 Seconds
item.description: Chandra's X-ray image of the Tarantula Nebula gives scientists a close-up view of the drama of star formation and star evolution.

item.title: PSR B1509-58 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A small dense object is responsible for the remarkably complex and intriguing structures seen in this image from the Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: NGC 604 in 60 Seconds
item.description: NGC 604 is a divided neighborhood in the galaxy M33, where some 200 hot, young massive stars reside.

item.title: Crab Nebula in 60 Seconds
item.description: The Crab Nebula is one of the best-known images ever taken by the Chandra X-ray Observatory.

item.title: M101 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image of the spiral galaxy Messier 101 is a composite of observations from NASA's three Great Observatories.

item.title: Abell 85 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The composite image shows the galaxy cluster known as Abell 85, which is located about 740 million light years from Earth.

item.title: 3-D Fly-Through of Cassiopeia A
item.description: For the first time, a multiwavelength three-dimensional (3-D) reconstruction of a supernova remnant has been created.

item.title: G292.01+8 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image shows how complex a star's afterlife can be.

item.title: M84 in 60 Seconds
item.description: M84 is a massive elliptical galaxy located about 55 million light years from Earth in the Virgo Cluster.

item.title: M87 in 60 Seconds
item.description: M87 is a giant elliptical galaxy. At a distance of about 60 million light-years from Earth, M87 is the largest galaxy in the Virgo cluster of some 2,000 galaxies.

item.title: Abell 1689 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Abell 1689 is a massive cluster of galaxies located about 2.3 billion light-years away.

item.title: SN1996cr in 60 Seconds
item.description: In 1995 or 1996 a supernova exploded in a nearby galaxy, but no one on Earth knew it at the time.

item.title: RCW 108 in 60 Seconds
item.description: RCW 108 is a region where stars are actively forming about 4,000 light-years from Earth.

item.title: Perseus A in 60 Seconds
item.description: The giant galaxy, Perseus A, which is also known as NGC 1275, is a well-known source of strong radio radiation.

item.title: Cat's Eye Nebula in 60 Seconds Plus
item.description: This composite of data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Hubble Space Telescope is another look for NGC 6543, better known as the Cat's Eye nebula.

item.title: Macs J0025.4-1222 in 60 Seconds Plus
item.description: Two galaxy clusters, each a quadrillion times the mass of the Sun, collided to form the system formally known as Macs J0025.4-1222.

item.title: M81 in 60 Seconds
item.description: This image of the mammoth spiral galaxy M81, located about 12 million light years away, contains data from four different NASA satellites.

item.title: SN 1006 in 60 Seconds
item.description: The brightest supernova ever recorded on Earth, this spectacular light show was documented in China, Japan, Europe, and the Arab world. It was brighter than Venus, and visible during the day for weeks.

item.title: Centaurus A in 60 Seconds
item.description: There is nothing subtle about the black hole in the galaxy Centaurus A. First off, it's about 10 million times more massive than the sun, and Chandra's X-ray image shows it's not just sitting quietly as a bright point in the middle.

item.title: NGC 4258 in 60 Seconds
item.description: A composite image of NGC 4258, about 25 million light-years from Earth, shows an X-shaped pattern when seen in different types of light.

item.title: G1.9+0.3 in 60 Seconds
item.description: About a hundred and forty years ago, the light from a supernova explosion in our galaxy reached the Earth, but no one saw it. The discovery of this supernova remnant helps astronomers better understand how often these stellar time-bombs go off in our galaxy.

item.title: 3C321 in 60 Seconds
item.description: In 3C321, a jet from a black hole in one of the galaxies is pummeling its neighbor galaxy, the first time this type of galactic violence has ever been seen. The jet could bring big trouble for any planets in its path, but could also trigger a burst of star formation in its wake.

item.title: Sombrero Galaxy in 60 Seconds
item.description: Like the Milky Way, Sombrero is a spiral galaxy. However, we see Sombrero edge-on from our vantage point from Earth, rather than the face-down perspective that is more familiar.

item.title: Kepler's Supernova Remnant in 60 Seconds
item.description: The supernova explosion that created this object was witnessed on Earth about 400 ago years by many skywatchers, including the astronomer Johannes Kepler. This object, which now bears Kepler's name, is the remains of a massive star's demise.

item.title: M82 in 60 Seconds
item.description: When seen in visible light from the Hubble Space Telescope, M82 looks like an ordinary spiral galaxy.

item.title: The Crab Nebula in 60 Seconds
item.description: In 1054 A.D., a star's death in the constellation Taurus was observed on Earth. Now, almost a thousand years later, a superdense neutron star left behind by the explosion is spewing out a blizzard of extremely high-energy particles into the expanding debris field known as the Crab Nebula.

item.title: M51 in 60 Seconds
item.description: Hubble's image of M51, also known as the Whirlpool Galaxy, shows the majestic spiral arms that are actually long lanes of stars and gas laced with dust. The infrared image from Spitzer also reveals stars and the glow from clouds of interstellar dust.

item.title: Cassiopeia A in 60 Seconds
item.description: Cassiopeia A is the 300-year-old remnant created by the supernova explosion of a massive star. Each Great Observatory image highlights different characteristics of the remnant.
